text.p: Following are the top stories from selected Singapore newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- King Norodom Sihanouk authorised Cambodia's acting head of state to appoint Foreign Minister Ung Huot as the country's First Prime Minister.
- A mathematician, an entrepreneur, a social activist, a statutory board and an arts group received the Excellence for Singapore award yesterday for being the best in their fields.

- The Thai King summoned Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh to the palace to be briefed on the state of the country's economy, amid strong rumours that his government would be toppled by a military coup.

- Apple shares were soaring as investors reacted to news that arch-rival Microsoft had taken a US$150-million stake in the ailing computer company, while analysts said the deal makes sense to the software giant by easing anti-trust concerns of US regulators.
- Local tranche shares had a field day, gaining 4 to 6 percent, while foreign shares came off on market speculation that the two classes of shares might converge.
- Wing Tai Holdings will be allowed to convert the Cockpit Hotel site into a commercial and residential development -- but the project will be at least 20 percent smaller than it had hoped for.
- Former Merrill Lynch private banker Kevin Wallace has sought permission from the Hong Kong police and judiciary to travel to Singapore to face a court cross-examination on his assets, sources said.
- ST Computer Systems & Services dropped a bombshell when it announced that its foreign and local shares will be traded as one from today.
- Indonesian stocks tumbled over a potpouri of concerns -- central bank efforts to tighten liquidity, the weaker rupiah slashing corporate earnings and talk of a major bank in financial trouble.
- The Malaysian central bank quashed widespread rumours that its governor, Ahmad Don, had quit.
- The government-linked Singapore Technologies group is in talks to buy a majority stake in healthcare group Beng & Ooi as part of a plan to become a regional healthcare player.
- Theme restaurant Hard Rock Cafe wants to grow its own chain of hotels and resorts worldwide -- and local tycoon Ong Beng Seng will have a hand in it.
- Koh Brothers' G&W Group, positioned as an infrastructure play, launched its mainboard initial public offer yesterday of 27 million new shares.

- Scotts Investments, the Jumabhoys' family holding company, has informed Scotts Holdings that the deal to buy back 12.95 million Scotts shares from Rafiq Jumabhoy has not been completed as scheduled.
- Camerlin Pte Ltd has booked a profit of about S$13.5 million from the sale of its 9 percent stake in National Foods, says the head of the Australian-based food company.
